<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_maximize_write_buffer:
```c
static size_t
connection_maximize_write_buffer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = connection->pool;
  void *new_buf;
  size_t new_size;
  size_t free_size;

  mhd_assert ((NULL != c->write_buffer) || (0 == c->write_buffer_size));
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset >= c->write_buffer_send_offset);
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_size >= c->write_buffer_append_offset);

  free_size = MHD_pool_get_free (pool);
  if (0 != free_size)
  {
    new_size = c->write_buffer_size + free_size;
    /* This function must not move the buffer position.
     * MHD_pool_reallocate () may return the new position only if buffer was
     * allocated 'from_end' or is not the last allocation,
     * which should not happen. */
    mhd_assert ((NULL == c->write_buffer) || \
                MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool, c->write_buffer, \
                                               c->write_buffer_size));
    new_buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                   c->write_buffer,
                                   c->write_buffer_size,
                                   new_size);
    mhd_assert ((c->write_buffer == new_buf) || (NULL == c->write_buffer));
    c->write_buffer = new_buf;
    c->write_buffer_size = new_size;
    if (c->write_buffer_send_offset == c->write_buffer_append_offset)
    {
      /* All data have been sent, reset offsets to zero. */
      c->write_buffer_send_offset = 0;
      c->write_buffer_append_offset = 0;
    }
  }

  return c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments in the function were not selected because they do not present plausible unreachable-code issues: - Declarations and the aliasing assignment (struct pointer declarations and 'struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection;') are simple definitions executed when the function is entered and cannot be statically unreachable. - The call and assignment 'free_size = MHD_pool_get_free (pool);' is an ordinary function call whose result controls the if-condition; the call itself is reachable. Whether the if-body executes depends on the runtime return value (hence the if-block was selected for investigation), but the call itself is not unreachable. - Simple assignments after a successful reallocation (e.g. 'c->write_buffer = new_buf;' and 'c->write_buffer_size = new_size;') are reachable only as part of the if-body and are therefore covered by that selected fragment. - The final return statement ('return c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset;') is the function exit point and is reachable on every control path, so it does not indicate unreachable code. - Comment lines and the overall function signature do not introduce unreachable code. The selected fragments cover all points where control-flow might make code unreachable (the conditional expansion path, the inner reset branch, and the assertions documenting invariants). Other lines are either obviously reachable or are subsumed by those selected regions.
